A patient is hyperventilating due to anx: Coach the patient to slow their breathing; do not have them breathe into a paper bag.
A 45-year-old male is experiencing chest: Administer high-flow oxygen and prepare for rapid transport while monitoring vital signs.
You arrive on scene to find an unrespons: Check for responsiveness and call for help/activate EMS if not already done.
When using an AED, what should you do if: Remove the patch and wipe the area clean before applying the AED pads.
What does the acronym SAMPLE stand for i: Signs/Symptoms, Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last oral intake, Events leading up to the incident
When should you use a non-rebreather mas: When a patient requires high-concentration oxygen delivery (10-15 LPM for 90%+ oxygen concentration)
What does OPQRST stand for when assessin: Onset, Provocation, Quality, Radiation, Severity, Time
What is the maximum time an EMT should s: 10 minutes or less (Platinum 10 minutes/Golden Hour principle)
A child has a partial airway obstruction: Encourage continued coughing and do not interfere; monitor closely.
When treating a patient with suspected s: Manual in-line stabilization, apply cervical collar, and secure to a backboard or appropriate spinal motion restriction device.
What are the signs of adequate breathing: Rate of 12-20 breaths/min, adequate tidal volume, regular rhythm, bilateral chest rise, and clear breath sounds.
What is the proper depth for chest compr: At least 2 inches (5 cm) but no more than 2.4 inches (6 cm)
What are the 'Hs and Ts' that represent: Hypovolemia, Hypoxia, Hydrogen ion (acidosis), Hypo/Hyperkalemia, Hypothermia, Tension pneumothorax, Tamponade (cardiac), Toxins, Thrombosis (pulmonary/coronary)
How should you treat a patient with an e: Cover with a sterile dressing moistened with saline, do not attempt to push organs back in, and keep the patient warm.
A patient with COPD history is in respir: Start with lower concentration and titrate to maintain SpO2 of 88-92%, while closely monitoring respiratory effort.
What position should a patient in shock: Supine with legs elevated (Trendelenburg or shock position)
When is it appropriate to use an orophar: In unconscious patients with no gag reflex
What is the APGAR score used for?: Assessing newborn vital signs at 1 and 5 minutes after birth (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respirations)
A construction worker has an impaled obj: Stabilize the object in place with bulky dressings, do not remove it, and transport.
What is the Rule of 9s used for in emerg: To estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in order to assess burn severity and guide treatment.
How does the Rule of 9s differ for infan: In infants/children, the head represents a larger percentage (18%) and each leg represents a smaller percentage (14%), due to different body proportions.
What is the 'palmar method' for estimati: The patient's palm (including fingers) represents approximately 1% of their total body surface area, useful for estimating scattered or irregular burns.
An adult patient has burns to the entire: 19% (anterior right leg 9% + anterior left leg 9% + genitals 1%)
At what TBSA percentage is a burn genera: Burns greater than 20-25% TBSA, or greater than 10% TBSA if full-thickness (third-degree)
What three components are assessed in th: Facial droop, arm drift, and speech abnormalities
How do you assess facial droop using the: Ask the patient to smile or show their teeth and observe if both sides of the face move equally.
What is a normal finding when assessing: Both sides of the face move equally and symmetrically.
What is an abnormal finding when assessi: One side of the face does not move as well as the other, or droops.
How do you assess arm drift using the Ci: Ask the patient to close their eyes and extend both arms straight out, palms up, for 10 seconds.
What is a normal finding when assessing: Both arms move equally, or neither arm moves/drifts.
What is an abnormal finding when assessi: One arm does not move, or one arm drifts downward compared to the other.
How do you assess speech using the Cinci: Ask the patient to repeat a simple phrase such as 'You can't teach an old dog new tricks.'
What is a normal finding when assessing: The patient says the correct words clearly without slurring.
What is an abnormal finding when assessi: The patient slurs words, uses incorrect or inappropriate words, or is unable to speak.
What does the mnemonic FAST stand for in: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911
What are the three categories assessed i: Eye opening, verbal response, and motor response
What is decorticate posturing and what d: Arms flexed and drawn toward the core with legs extended; indicates damage to the cerebral hemispheres or area above the brainstem.
What is decerebrate posturing and what d: Arms and legs extended with arms rotated inward; indicates damage to the brainstem and is generally a worse prognostic sign than decorticate posturing.
How do you document a GCS score?: Report the total score and individual component scores (e.g., GCS 11 = E3 V4 M4)
Why is it important to document individu: Individual scores provide more specific information about the patient's neurological status and help track changes in specific functions over time.
